summary: Cleaning Up Old Dotfiles and Symlinks

message.content: hello claude! in rcm how can i set a folder to "not get the dot prefix

content.text: In rcm, you can prevent a folder from getting the dot prefix by using the `UNDOTTED` directive in your `rcrc` file.

content.content:
1→COPY_ALWAYS="ssh/id_*"
     2→DOTFILES_DIRS="/home/skogix/.dotfiles"
     3→HOSTNAME="skogix-workstation"
     4→SYMLINK_DIRS=""
     5→EXCLUDES="README* LICENSE* *.md .gitignore .git tags"
     6→UNDOTTED="bin"
     7→TAGS=""

file.content:
COPY_ALWAYS="ssh/id_*"
DOTFILES_DIRS="/home/skogix/.dotfiles"
HOSTNAME="skogix-workstation"
SYMLINK_DIRS=""
EXCLUDES="README* LICENSE* *.md .gitignore .git tags"
UNDOTTED="bin"
TAGS=""

content.text:
Perfect! You already have `UNDOTTED="bin"` in your rcrc file (line 6). This means the `bin` folder won't get the dot prefix when symlinked.

To add more folders that shouldn't get the dot prefix, just add them to the `UNDOTTED` line separated by spaces:

```bash
UNDOTTED="bin folder1 folder2"
```

This way, `bin/`, `folder1/`, and `folder2/` will be symlinked as `~/bin/`, `~/folder1/`, and `~/folder2/` instead of `~/.bin/`, `~/.folder1/`, etc.
